title: 112_hr2964
content: The "Unfunded Mandates Accountability Act of 2011" aims to improve regulatory analysis and review to make government more accountable to the public by disclosing key information underlying agency decisions. This Act emphasizes the importance of understanding the benefits and costs of regulations on individuals, employers, and governments. SEC. 3. Amends Section 202 of the Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 to require regulatory impact analyses for certain rules. The Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 is amended to require agencies to prepare and publish regulatory impact analyses for proposed rules with significant economic effects. The term 'cost' is defined to include compliance costs and indirect costs. Agencies must conduct initial and final regulatory impact analyses for rules that may have a significant economic impact. The Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 now mandates agencies to conduct initial and final regulatory impact analyses for proposed rules with significant economic effects. The analyses must include an assessment of anticipated benefits and costs, quantified to the extent feasible, as well as alternatives that require no federal action or utilize incentives and market-based approaches to achieve desired outcomes. The Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 requires agencies to conduct regulatory impact analyses for proposed rules with significant economic effects. The analyses must include an assessment of benefits and costs, alternatives that require no federal action, and estimates of budgetary effects on different regions of the nation. The Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 mandates agencies to conduct regulatory impact analyses for proposed rules, including assessing job creation or loss and consulting with elected representatives of affected State, local, and tribal governments. In subsection (d), "subsection (a)" is replaced with "subsection (b)", and in subsection (e), "subsection (a)" is replaced with "subsection (b". SEC. 4 amends Section 205 of the Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 to require agencies to identify and consider multiple regulatory alternatives before proposing a rule, selecting the least burdensome option that achieves the statute's objectives. SEC. 5 extends this requirement to independent regulatory agencies. SEC. 5 amends the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 to include independent regulatory agencies. It also adds an exemption for monetary policy rules proposed by the Federal Reserve System. SEC. 6 addresses judicial review under the Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995. SEC. 401 grants parties the right to judicial review of final agency actions for compliance with specific sections. Courts with jurisdiction over rule compliance can review claims under this section and order agencies to take remedial action. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act will be effective 90 days after enactment.
